comments.html:
Does anybody know if there is the possibility to override the upstream DNS server's TTL value?
Sometimes, DNS queries are being answered with a TTL value of 0, and the router does not store them (or marks them as expired the second they arrive). So the router will send out a query to the same host the next time. Is there any remedy against this?
Thanks alot for your help!
comments.name: Anonymous

comments.html: As far as I'm aware, IOS cannot do that. Usually there's a good reason the reply is sent back with TTL=0 (for example, multi-server load balancing implemented with DNS).
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html: OK then -- thanks alot for your answer!
comments.name: Anonymous

comments.html: I have set up caching dns server on a Cisco 876. Problem is that requests are accepted on all interfaces, including the outside interface. What's a good method to limit the router to only handle requests arriving on specific interfaces? Thanks!
comments.name: Anonymous

comments.html:
@Anonymous#3: Inbound access list (ACL) on the outside interface(s).

Having an ACL that blocks all unwanted traffic is mandatory on interfaces connected to a public network (for example, the Internet).
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html:
actually ACLs are not looked at when using the ip dns server on IOS

best way i have found is to set up NAT on the outside interface, and just NAT all incoming traffic on port 53 to a dummy address
comments.name: Anonymous
